docs.snippet: FIELDS KARP-Marje. January 27, 1998. Services Friday, 9:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. She is predeceased by her husband, Oscar Karp. Survived by her niece, Sue Ruskin-Mayher, her nephew, Marc Greene, two great-nie...
docs.lead_paragraph: FIELDS KARP-Marje. January 27, 1998. Services Friday, 9:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. She is predeceased by her husband, Oscar Karp. Survived by her niece, Sue Ruskin-Mayher, her nephew, Marc Greene, two great-nieces, Nicole and Joanna Ruskin. In lieu of flowers, donations can by made to the Alzheimer's Association or the Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital, NY, NY 10013.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIELDS KARP, MARJE

docs.snippet: Walter Bishop Jr., a jazz pianist who recorded with Charlie Parker, Miles Davis and others, died on Saturday at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan.    The cause was a heart attack, said his sister, M...
docs.lead_paragraph: Walter Bishop Jr., a jazz pianist who recorded with Charlie Parker, Miles Davis and others, died on Saturday at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 70 and lived in Manhattan. The cause was a heart attack, said his sister, Marian Jeffries.
docs.abstract: Walter Bishop Jr, jazz pianist, dies at age 70; photo (M)

headline.main: Walter Bishop Jr., 70, Jazz Pianist Who Rode Be-Bop's First Wave

docs.snippet: Jayson Williams has long been known for his sense of humor. But many are just finding out that this class clown can also play. Just check the National Basketball Association's rebounding leaders on a daily basis.    Outside New Jersey, however, th...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jayson Williams has long been known for his sense of humor. But many are just finding out that this class clown can also play. Just check the National Basketball Association's rebounding leaders on a daily basis. Outside New Jersey, however, the accolades have taken their time arriving. Until today.
docs.abstract: New Jersey Nets forward Jayson Williams discusses his selection to NBA All-Star Game (M)

docs.snippet: NEWS  Upbeat     When it comes to busy people, put Christoph Eschenbach near the top of the list. A maestro very much in motion, he'll be at Avery Fisher Hall tomorrow, Friday and Saturday, as well as on Feb. 3, to lead the New York Philharmonic i...
docs.lead_paragraph: NEWS Upbeat When it comes to busy people, put Christoph Eschenbach near the top of the list. A maestro very much in motion, he'll be at Avery Fisher Hall tomorrow, Friday and Saturday, as well as on Feb. 3, to lead the New York Philharmonic in performances of Bruckner's Symphony No. 8. This is his first appearance in eight years as guest conductor of the Philharmonic. Mr. Eschenbach, who began his career as a pianist, has been music director of the Houston Symphony since 1988 and music director of the Ravinia Festival since 1994. At the end of next season, he is scheduled to lay down his baton in Houston and assume directorship of the Hamburg NDR Symphony Orchestra while becoming artistic director of the Schleswig-Holstein Music Festival. In the Running For those who like to match wits with the experts, here's the early line on the best-director sweepstakes at this year's Academy Awards. The Directors Guild of America, whose prize winner has prefigured the winner of the Oscar for best director all but four times since the organization's first presentation in 1949, has made its nominations: James Cameron for ''Titanic,'' Steven Spielberg for ''Amistad,'' James L. Brooks for ''As Good as It Gets,'' Curtis Hanson for ''L.A. Confidential'' and Gus Van Sant for ''Good Will Hunting.'' The Directors Guild award will be presented in New York and Los Angeles on March 7. And speaking of the Academy Award ceremony, which is scheduled for March 23: Oscar is finally going to get his own theme music, performed by an 83-piece orchestra. It's ''Fanfare for Oscar,'' composed by Jerry Goldsmith, himself an Oscar winner in 1977 for the score of ''The Omen.'' Calling the assignment a ''daunting challenge,'' Mr. Goldsmith added, ''The end result of the 45-second composition is a melding of the Hollywood of the past, the Hollywood of the present and the Hollywood of the future.'' Flight Plan Bertolt Brecht and the American director Robert Wilson will be the guiding spirits when Charles A. Lindbergh flies again, tonight in Berlin in a Berliner Ensemble production commemorating the centennial of Brecht's birth. The production, adapted and staged by Mr. Wilson for the theater founded by Brecht, is derived from ''Der Ozeanflug,'' written by Brecht as a radio play in 1928. The work traces Lindbergh's historic nonstop solo flight from New York to Paris the previous year. Brecht was born on Feb. 10, 1898, and died in East Berlin in 1956. For a Cause With Ron Rifkin (of ''Cabaret''), Adam Alexi-Malle (''Goose-Pimples'') and David Margulies (''Bashevis'') in leading roles, the American premiere reading of ''Look, Europe!'' was presented on Monday night at the Actors Studio. The drama, written by a London-based Iranian playwright, Ghazi Rabihavi, was inspired by the case of an Iranian editor, Faraj Sarkuhi, who was arrested on Jan. 27, 1997, and sentenced to a year in prison on charges of espionage and ''slandering the Islamic Republic.'' Mr. Sarkuhi was among 134 writers who signed a petition in 1994 calling for greater freedom of expression. The reading was sponsored by PEN and the Actors Studio. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER INSIDE Aftermath A quarter-century after the historic lawsuit, a television documentary views the tumultuous life of Norma McCorvey, better known as the Roe of Roe v. Wade. Review, page 5.
docs.abstract: Christoph Eschenbach to be guest conductor of New York Philharmonic in performances of Bruckner's Symphony No. 8; photo; Directors Guild of America, whose prize winner has also won Oscar for best director all but four times since orgn's first presentations in 1949, makes it nominations: James Cameron for Titanic, Steven Spielberg for Amistad, James L Brooks for As Good As It Gets, Curtis Hanson for L.A. Confidential and Gus Van Sant for Good Will Hunting; photo of Oscar; Berliner Ensemble in Berlin to present play commemorating centennial of Bertolt Brecht's birth; Robert Wilson is adapting and staging work, written by Brecht as radio play based on Charles Lindbergh's flight; American premiere reading of Look, Europe!, by London-based Iranian playwright Ghazi Rabihavi, is presented at Actors Studio (M)

docs.snippet: In 1988, a year after a group of bright, aggressive Hollywood executives formed Castle Rock Entertainment, they experienced one of those serendipitous twists of fortune that defines the entertainment industry. Only this was one of the most amazing...
docs.lead_paragraph: In 1988, a year after a group of bright, aggressive Hollywood executives formed Castle Rock Entertainment, they experienced one of those serendipitous twists of fortune that defines the entertainment industry. Only this was one of the most amazing in television history, the beginning not only of a hot streak, but the sort of miracle the company could use now more than ever. Castle Rock, founded by a group of proteges of Norman Lear, the legendary producer of ''All in the Family,'' had won a contract to produce a sitcom for ABC called ''Past Imperfect.'' But a day before shooting was to begin, they decided the show's star, Dwight Schultz, was not going to work as the lead. In the scramble to find a replacement they got a call from George Shapiro, a cousin of Rob Reiner, the actor and director who was one of Castle Rock's founders. Mr. Shapiro, a talent manager, recommended one of his clients, a stand-up comic with little acting experience. His name was Jerry Seinfeld.
docs.abstract: Profile of Castle Rock Entertainment, television and movie production company that has known both fabulous good fortune and tough time; Castle Rock produced Seinfeld, but that is its sole success in television; movie division faces some tough questions; Castle Rock produced several hits in its first few years, but in recent years it has released films that did far better with critics than at box office; photo of Castle Rock principals: Glenn Padnick, Martin Shafer and Alan Horn (M)

docs.snippet: One could almost hear the computers tapping, faxes whirring, telephones ringing and photographers' cameras clicking as they raced to record a couture season more relevant than any in a long time. A newly energized couture has become a focal point ...
docs.lead_paragraph: One could almost hear the computers tapping, faxes whirring, telephones ringing and photographers' cameras clicking as they raced to record a couture season more relevant than any in a long time. A newly energized couture has become a focal point again for inspiration and trends. In the last five years, France's haute couture, once the reigning maharani of international fashion, has been relegated to marginal importance in directing style. Its decline followed the slide of French fashion generally and the parallel ascent of street influences on the high-fashion runway.
docs.abstract: Constance C R White reviews Paris fashions from designers Karl Lagerfeld, Yves St Laurent, Christian Lacroix and Jean-Paul Gaultier; photo (M)

headline.main: Review/Fashion; French Couture Sets Pace Again

docs.snippet: Effort Shifts for Bryant Park      When Seventh on Sixth announced ambitious plans for returning the women's collections to Bryant Park, it was on condition that a sufficient number of designers sign up. Now that at least 40 designers have committ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Effort Shifts for Bryant Park When Seventh on Sixth announced ambitious plans for returning the women's collections to Bryant Park, it was on condition that a sufficient number of designers sign up. Now that at least 40 designers have committed, the focus has shifted to the need for sponsorship to make the season financially feasible.
docs.abstract: Patterns column notes that Seventh on Sixth has received enough sponsors to make plans for returning women's collections to Bryant Park (S)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Among Margo Jefferson's ''Seven Unsung Novels Crying to Be Filmed'' [Jan. 18], there is one that has already been filmed, not once, but twice. That novel is Charles W. Chesnutt's ''House Behind the Cedars.'' The novel was first a...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Among Margo Jefferson's ''Seven Unsung Novels Crying to Be Filmed'' [Jan. 18], there is one that has already been filmed, not once, but twice. That novel is Charles W. Chesnutt's ''House Behind the Cedars.'' The novel was first adapted around 1925 by the pioneering black filmmaker Oscar Micheaux, who paid Chesnutt $500 for the rights to make a silent feature. As far as we know, no copies of this film exist.
docs.abstract: Letter by Richard Grupenhoff on Jan 18 article by Margo Jefferson on seven novels set in America between late 19th century and onset of World War I that should be considered as theatrical films (S)

docs.snippet: It's priest.    Have a little priest.    Is it really good?    Sir, it's too good, at least.    Then, of course, they don't commit sins of     the flesh.    So it's pretty fresh.      THE preceding words were brought to you by Stephen Sondheim, as...
docs.lead_paragraph: It's priest. Have a little priest. Is it really good? Sir, it's too good, at least. Then, of course, they don't commit sins of the flesh. So it's pretty fresh. THE preceding words were brought to you by Stephen Sondheim, as daring a composer-lyricist as the New York musical theater has produced. Who else but Mr. Sondheim would turn a meditation on cannibalism into an urbane Act One finale? The song, ''A Little Priest,'' was shocking only in its breathtaking expression of Mr. Sondheim's boundless (albeit dark and stormy) imagination. When I first heard it, at a matinee of ''Sweeney Todd, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street'' at the Uris (now the Gershwin) Theater in 1979, I went into a kind of ecstatic stupor. The rhymes fell so lightly on the ear; common phrases were arranged in arresting new juxtapositions. The number is a variation on what songwriters call a ''list song,'' in which a series of refrains reiterates one idea with multiple examples. In this case, it is the plans by Sweeney Todd, a homicidal barber (originally played by a wild-eyed Len Cariou), and Mrs. Lovett, the proprietress of a failing London pie shop (an angelically malicious Angela Lansbury), to slit the throats of his customers and bake them into meat pies. The cleverest song of its kind since Cole Porter's ''Let's Do It,'' in 1928, ''A Little Priest'' was just one example of Mr. Sondheim at the pinnacle of his powers. ''Sweeney Todd,'' which opened March 1, 1979, capped a decade of extraordinary musicals by the Manhattan-born composer. It began in 1970 with ''Company,'' his paean to neurotic New York relationships, and continued with the ravishing ''Follies'' (1971), the droll ''A Little Night Music'' (1973) and the cerebral (and underappreciated) ''Pacific Overtures'' (1976). By the time ''Sweeney Todd'' came to Broadway three years later, Mr. Sondheim had established himself as poet laureate of the musical theater, an artist and craftsman whose polished rhymes elevated lyric writing to a higher plane. Mr. Sondheim's career is also something of a lasting tribute to the great Broadway songwriters who preceded him, many of whom he consciously evokes in his scores. In the past, masters like Frank Loesser, Lerner and Loewe and Rodgers and Hart dominated Broadway in much the same way. And as both inheritor of the mantle of Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, at whose knee he learned his craft, and the composer most emulated by a generation of younger musical writers, Mr. Sondheim is the vital link between old forms and new. This turns out to be a mixed blessing, for many of those who have tried to follow his lead have proved to be only pale imitations. He is also the quintessential New York man of the theater, a home-grown talent in a home-grown industry. Many of his musicals, including ''Company,'' ''Follies,'' ''Merrily We Roll Along'' and the Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' portray New York types, mores and customs. Even ''Sweeney Todd,'' though it takes place in grimy, Hogarthian London, is infused with New York attitude: how else to describe Mrs. Lovett's brainstorm of turning corpses into munchies than as an example of the pragmatic New York-style seizing of a business opportunity? From the screeching factory whistle that prefaced the opening number to the grisly denouement, in which Mrs. Lovett was consigned by the demon barber to her own oven, the Grand Guignol-inspired ''Sweeney Todd'' was among the most unsettling musicals ever staged. The piercingly beautiful melodies, like ''Pretty Women'' and ''Green Finch and Linnet Bird,'' were ornate ruses, equal parts sugar and melancholy. The entire production, directed by Mr. Sondheim's longtime collaborator, Harold Prince, and designed by Eugene Lee to resemble a Victorian house of horrors, seemed perfumed with the sickly sweet odor of a slow-acting, poisonous gas. That was a key to its artistic success. Here was a musical that was not afraid to draw blood. Even lighthearted moments were underscored in the discordant tones of deep distress: an overwhelming sense of doom engulfed the audience the moment the lights went down. Though it won eight Tony Awards, including best musical, ''Sweeney Todd'' was not a hit on the order of mega-musicals like ''Cats'' and ''The Phantom of the Opera'' that would follow in the 1980's, the Andrew Lloyd Webber Decade for Broadway. ''Sweeney'' closed after 557 performances. But for me and, I suspect, many other theatergoers, that production is an abiding cultural landmark. It was a theater experience that had the power to make you swoon, as fixed in the memory as any Broadway playhouse is anchored to midtown bedrock.
docs.abstract: Peter Marks tribute to Stephen Sondheim, homegrown New York theater talent whose musicals include Sweeney Todd, the Demon Barber of Fleet Street; photo of 1979 production with Len Cariou and Angela Lansbury; list of longest-running Broadway shows (S)

Dear brother of Jacob and Asenath Petrie; adoring grandfather of Nathan Harrison and Oscar Schonfeld. Service Sunday, 11 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
